botanical_details.genus: Symphyotrichum includes around 90 species of annuals, biennials and perennials, mostly spread through the Americas, that were formerly included within the genus Aster. Leaves are simple, lance-shaped and entire, but it is their daisy-like flowerheads that they are grown for; central disc florets are typically yellow, surrounded by strap-shaped ray florets in shades of pink, blue, purple or white

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in moderately fertile, moist but well-drained soil in full sun or light shade. Stake plants if necessary, in early spring, see staking perennials. See aster cultivation for further advice
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by division in spring or root softwood basal cuttings in spring; division can be carried out every third year to maintain vigour
how_to_grow.pruning: Cut stems close to the ground in late autumn
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to leaf and bud eelworms, slugs and snails
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to Verticillium wilt, Powdery mildews and grey moulds
